info.title: Changes in the base system and the boot process

abstract.para: Let us dive into the foundational changes affecting system services, core libraries, and essential utilities.

section.title: Are there any changes to the boot loader in &slea; 16?
section.para: The boot loader in &slea; 16 is &grub; 2.12. BLS and &systemd;-boot are not used now, but may be added in the future.
On &x86-64;, full disk encryption is supported using PCR to unlock the disk if the TPM chip supports TPM v2.1 and later.

section.title: Where have the configuration files from /etc been moved?
section.para: &suse; continues to move configuration files delivered by &suse; from /etc to /usr. This solution enables you to maintain your settings in /etc without worrying about maintenance updates overwriting them. Even though many packages follow the paradigm, certain tools are still shipped with regular configuration files located in /etc. The process is still ongoing, and we expect that the other tools will be adapted in a future &slea; release.

You have three options for how to modify the configuration of a service or tool. For example, the tool frobnicator usually has configuration files in /etc/frob.conf. Starting with &slea; 16.0, the default configuration file of the tool is /usr/etc/frob.conf. Do not modify this file as it may be overwritten by future maintenance updates. To apply your custom changes, you have the following options:

listitem.para: Place your own copy of the configuration file into /etc/frob.conf, which has a precedence and the configuration file supplied by &suse; is then ignored.
You can place drop-in files into /etc/frob.d. The tool first loads the configuration from /usr/etc/frob.conf and then updates it using the drop-in files in /etc/frob.d.

important.title: Possible unexpected errors
important.para: This solution can lead to unexpected results if you have tools that try to update configuration files in /etc blindly. In particular, creating an empty /etc/ssh/sshd_config file may result in getting locked out of your system.

section.para: For more information and a list of affected packages, refer to configuration split details.

section.title: Are there any changes in the way the base system works in general?
section.para: Yes, /tmp is no longer persistent on reboot but uses tmpfs.

section.title: Do you support transactional updates in &sles;?
section.para: Currently, transactional updates are not supported on &sles;. The transactional update is supported by another product—&slm;.

section.title: Deprecated technologies in the base system
section.para: The following technologies have been deprecated:

listitem.para: nscd: The name service caching daemon
wicked: Replaced by &nm; for managing network connections
AppArmor: &selnx; is used exclusively as the security framework

section.title: What architecture level sets are supported?
section.para: The following table summarizes supported architecture level sets.

row.entry: Optimized v3 versions of certain shared libraries are now available. These libraries, which follow the naming scheme libfoo-x86_64_v3, are installed automatically on systems that support the new instruction set.
A 32-bit runtime is no longer supported, and &suse; does not provide any 32-bit libraries anymore.
&slea; 16.0 is supported on &power; 10 and &power; 11. Even though &slea; 16.0 continues to work on &power; 9 (except for KVM), this is not supported by &ibm;.
Support for a 32-bit runtime has been discontinued since SLES 15 SP3.

section.title: Do you still support legacy BIOS on &x86-64;?
section.para: The default for fresh installations of &slea; 16.0 is UEFI. Support for legacy BIOS is deprecated and will be removed in a future version of the product. However, support for legacy BIOS is provided for backward compatibility in the following scenarios:

listitem.para: migration of VMs that use Legacy BIOS

section.para: Some features may not be available when using Legacy BIOS, such as full disk encryption with TPM.
